40777739.review:
TLDR:
Solid HOP play with some other puzzles for variety saddled with a fremium design that limits play time to encourage spending money.

This game has a variety of Locations to search for items that complete the quests you are given over time. There are a variety of NPCs to provide dialogue to explain why you're searching each location. The puzzles have multiple settings for where objects might be hidden to provide some variety and make it less about rote memorization. Each location has an energy cost to explore that goes up as you level the location.

In addition to the HOPs, there are several different puzzles for the opening of four different types of chests. Chests, which also use energy, contain various types of objects that either provide access to locations, unlock boost locations, or complete collections. Most of the collections are parts of quests, though not all.

If it were *just* an HOP game with some tweaks, I'd give it a solid 9 rating.

However....

This is a fremium game, and the puzzles are gated by energy, the standard roadblock of fremium games everywhere. 

That said, as of yet I haven't run into any actual paywalls, just the frustration of having to stop just as I'm getting on a roll.

The energy recharges a bit slowly for the energy costs to explore locations, but you can still play a couple of times per day. Energy can be restored by using items that provide additional energy and are sometimes rewarded for completing quests or objectives.

There are also various non-HOP locations that can be repaired provided you have enough of the necessary materials, which are given as rewards as well as acquired through the opening of chests. Some locations increase your maximum energy, others increase the speed at which it recharges or reduce the time required, while some provide various types of items.

One type of item that can be acquired a variety of ways are access keys. Some of the locations require that you have items in order to access them. This is a bit of a roadblock at first, but I've found that after a while, you end up with a surplus of the item in question and it stops being an issue.

The graphics are standard and display well, and the music is pleasant without being obtrusive or jarring. The sound effects for interacting with creatures can get a little repetitive if you have a mission to deal with more than just a few of them. Also, the intro dialogue will start playing every time you launch the game, though it is skippable.

Also, there is an audio glitch that happens to me every so often where the volume is much louder than I've set it. If I stop and restart, it then plays at the correct level.

Altogether, a solid HOP+ game stuffed into an irritating but not game-stopping fremium framework.

Pros:
Solid HOP gameplay
Item locations vary within sets
A few other puzzles for additional variety

Cons:
Energy required to do almost anything
Locations gated by items to encourage spending money
Some sounds can be repetitive

Final Score: 7.5

40117828.review:
The Lost Lands series are a traditional fantasy setting, with a variety of standard tropes to intice players with their familiarity. The game shows a high standard of art and contains an array of puzzle types to keep it varied and interesting.
As a casual game it shows the usual techniques to keep players returning, from daily log in rewards to energy points that replenish over a set period.
As a free to play game, and a single player game, it doesn't require you to spend money unless you are impatient and want to progress faster. Of course this impatience requires you to spend more as you progress and I assume this is how they allow the game to make money. It feels more like a mobile phone game with this feature than a steam game but nevertheless the gem packages are not so intrusive as to be annoying. What is annoying is the highly intrusive marketing for BN-Games's paid games, with no option to remove this. It flashes at you at the beginning of the game and demands you must click on it before moving on into the rest of the game. There is no option to remove it.

The artwork is usually gorgeous and the environment and locals are beuatifully staged with a variety of positions for each object and the objects have various forms that allows them to blend into the background.
The character portraits are slightly weird though. The character anatomy is poor (especially on the female characters) and the movement is unnatural and unsettling rather than more close to life.

The puzzles are delivered in the form of chests to unlock, and exhibit a variety of types lifted straight from mobile games. This is not a bad thing though as it is pleasant to have the different types to change the game every now and then, and choose a different skill to exercise. 

The story is apparently unfinished, with no support seeming to come from the game developers to continue it further, however the games content as it is, holds plenty since progression is fairly slow (I didn't pay to progress). This might be the major factor not to recommend the game, that is is indeed quite slow and in doing so may feel repetitive despite having strategies implemented into its design to prevent this.

As a free-to-play game I definitely recommend this despite the various flaws.

39970241.review:
Time stated does not match play time.
I do not normally play hidden object games so I am not familiar with what is normal in the genre. I will say that I like the game, the plot is good, the maps(?) are interresting and detailed. Items normally, but not always (I am looking at you fountain), appear in places that make sense for them to be there. The missions are simple to figure out and if you forget there is a goto you can use to do whatever is next.
The problems that stop me from giving a higher mental rating are first the energy system.
Giving the game a night to recharge   EDIT (A full night to recharge is not enough once you get about half way through) END EDIT   will mean something like three maps before you have to wait again. This is the main (maybe only) way that the game lasts more than a few days at most to complete (I admittedly have not finished the game but if my progress with the energy system is any indication just by official time played alone I should have long finished the game). I hate the energy system, it is an annoying gimic that prolongs the game and has absolutely no benifit whatso ever.
The other problems are less pervassive and mostly easy to over look. So problem two is that some items leave a "shadow" the biggest offender so far is the slingshot at the fisherman's hut. Basically what happens is the items have multiple spots they show up, sometime an item will appear in a secondary spot but leave in the main spot a less clear but still able to identify image. While annoying it is not as bad as the main problem. 
Problem three is two parts, in the game there is more than one way to find out what you are searching for, by name and by shadow outline. The shadows are confusing some of them you could swear are not what they are supposed to be (pumpkin, skeleton and what ever that plant is) as it is a shadow outline what you think is a container or at least a cyclinder will turn out to be something completely different. (The skeleton looks nothing like its outline, there is no way aroung that one.)  The problem (easily argued a feature) with the names is that certain items which make sense in context also have the same name as completely different items. What this means is that you may be looking for an item that you have seen in other parts of the game, then after not finding it and time running out use an item which is difficult to get without paying real money and find out that the thing that you have glanced right past multiple times (and looks nothing like waht you were looking for) is the item you need. The name is valid and not even unusual it just trips you brecause you have been looking for the other item all this time then suddenly get this other thing instead.
The game also experiences freezes when they try to sell you stuff. Leaving the game either by opening something else or just waiting is enough for it to fix itself but it is still annoying. 

Final say is that it is an OK game, just scrap the energy and the game freezeing sales and good to go. The game does have ingame purchases (which I ignore) but they are not [i]needed[/i] to win the game (just win fast by buying energy) I say good for very short distractions, just whatever you do, do not get attached or you will end up buying energy and wasting money.

39147865.review:
Lost Lands: A Hidden Object Adventure интересный квест в стиле «поиска предметов». 
Дом эльфов уничтожен и в поисках нового они отправляются за моря. Их корабли причаливают к заброшенному острову и начинают обустраиваться на новом месте. Впереди эльфов ждет много опасностей и приключений.
В игре красивая графика. Карта острова открывается постепенно, с выполнением заданий. Собирая ресурсы, вы можете строить новые здания. Они помогут вам бороться с волшебными противниками, обитающими на острове. Заходя в игру каждый день, вы будете получать награду и чем больше дней заходите, тем награда становится более весомая. Также в игре есть множество коллекций, собирая которые вы получите монеты и разнообразные бонусы. 
Для получения всех достижений вам потребуется 100 и более часов. В игре имеется прогресс выполнения достижений. Это очень удобно, так как в Stim не очень понятно сколько раз локацию нужно пройти, чтобы получить то или иное достижение. Обычно накопительные достижения в других играх отображаются без прогресса.
Если вас не пугает много раз проходить тот или другой уровень, то это игра для вас. Спокойно и не спеша можно проходить эту игру каждый день. К тому же в игре есть русский язык, и она бесплатная!
Рекомендую всем любителям поиска предметов!
Оценка 10/10

39068020.review:
Pro:
+kostenlos

Contra:
+ aufgezwungenes "Tutorial" das, ähnlich wie bei gewissen Smartphonespielen einfach nur die ersten Minuten im Spiel den kompletten Bildschirm mit Pfeilen zutackert
+ seltsames Level- und Lootsystem, dass in einem Wimmelbildspiel nichts zu suchen hat und nur auf Mikrotransaktionen ausgelegt ist
+ 3 (drei!!!) Ingamewährungen, Gold, Diamanten und Energie, ein weiter Auswuchs der Monetarisierung
+ durch oben genanntes komisches, sinnloses Gegenstandsystem muss man alle Schauplätze gefühlt 100 mal spielen
+ vollgeklatschtes Menü mit einer Menge Dinge die ein solches Spiel nicht braucht
+ Boni, die man auch nicht braucht (zumindest sollte so etwas in einem guten, oder auch nur okayen Spiel nicht mal existent sein) bekommt man nicht einfach, nein, auch diese werden auf den eh schon überladenen Bildschirm geklatscht und man sammelt sie mit der Maus ein
+ Questgegenstände bekommt man häufig beim Spielen der dafür erforderlichen Level nicht - dies ist entweder ein Bug oder absicht um noch mehr Energie zu verbrauchen und damit Mikrotransaktionen zu generieren
+ Errungenschaften sind komplett verbuggt

Fazit:
Ich hätte mich über ein simples WImmelbildspiel mit altbekannter Mechanik gefreut. Ich hab keine übertrieben gute Story oder sonstige Innovationen erwartet, denn diese Art von casual games lebt davon, dass man genau das bekommt was man kennt, und auch erwartet. Bekommen habe ich etwas, dessen Benutzeroberfläche unübersichtlicher nicht sein könnte und eher an eine Art Clash of Clans (oder ähnliche) oder sonstige Geldkuhmelkmaschinen für mobile Devices erinnert. Überall ploppen sinnlose Extras und Boni auf, ständig wird auf den Shop verwiesen, ich muss jedes Level oft durchspielen um irgendwelche Teile für irgendwelche Questgegenstände zu bekommen. Die Story, die ja nicht mal gut sein muss, rückt dadurch komplett in den Hintergrund und Spielfluss kommt schon gar keiner auf.
Im Endeffekt hätte das wahrscheinlich ein gutes Spiel werden können, wurde aber durch Implementierung der ganzen Mikrotransaktionspestilenz zu einer einzigen Grausamkeit. Dieses Review verfasse ich im Übrigen gerade nur, weil ich nicht weiterspielen konnte, da meine Energie alle war. Warum ein Wimmelbildspiel so etwas braucht? Ich weiß es auch nicht.

38336652.review:
The developers ask for a review too fast IMO, before you have a chance to know how the different elements work. Completed all available quests I can update my first opinion.
The game looks well and the background music is nice. The HO scenes are repetitive and the objects you have to find are placed in the same way what makes me feel a bit strange because the difficulty appears to not increasing at all. Yes, you have to gradually spend more energy to explore the locations and find more and more hidden objects but after finishing about 20 explorations you'll know much better where to look for the items.
The quests are rather linear and mostly related to eliminating some monsters, gathering specified items or collections and visiting the places (also in night mode - like with a flashlight).
Some locations require special items to enter each time but that's the moment when repairing damaged structures comes in handy. These buildings let you gather more energy, accelerate it's regeneration or provide some resources to advance.
The chests are interesting addition - each type provides a bit different set of loot and requires to solve a puzzle.
Some criticize energy system but there are means to regain it faster by using special potions and amulets. These boosters can be obtained as rewards for assembling part of the collections or successfully exploring some locations.
The only disadvantage of the game is it's incomplete state - the history is unfinished and once you reach some point you'll be informed that the game will be updated soon. Let us hope so.

Fun little time-killer, and the microtransactions are relatively unobtrusive which is all you can ask for in a f2p. Lost Lands certainly delivers above and beyond what you'd expect in a f2p game as far as visual quality. The settings are pretty to look at.


Pros: 
- cutesy (if formulaic) story behind the game
- interplay between building, chest puzzles, enemies, and item collections keeps things interesting

Cons:
- achievements take a lifetime to earn since you need to max them out as opposed to Lost Lands: Mahjong
- energy costs & regeneration could really use some reworking given how quickly you can run through object rounds
- some of the English language needs tweaking. it's still readable but certainly...comes off awkwardly.

35901354.review:
As a person who played this game for 63 hours, I can't believe people actually recommend this game. This review is also based on the fact that I intend to complete this game 100%.

Pros:
-good graphics
-nice maps, some hidden places are really cool
-you have to rebuild an island to increase your energy/get rewards
-the island is also inhabited by creatures that you have to kill with weapons you get from exploring the areas
-quests and opening chests add a nice twist to the game

Cons:
-you can only play once a day (20-30min should be enough) since the energy recharges really slow
-after some time the game becomes really repetitive - there are 16 areas to discover and you need to play 100-120 times each area, every object has around 5 places - you will just end up clicking on the screen for no reason without even checking the items
-alot of bugs, most visual and text related - however the most annoying is the fact that energy recharges way slower when the game is not open - and even if you leave it open you can't leave it in background because it will pause the game and the energy will stop from recharging
-the amulet that recharges energy faster is also not working when the game is not open - it actually recharges energy slower when you leave the game - major severity bug
-the game takes way too long to complete 100% (I only managed to get 7 achievements in 63 hours)
-you have to play for 1-2 years to complete this 100% : 20-40 minutes every day
-updates are almost never available nowadays for the bug fixes

This game is nice if you want to play for some hours since it is free, but it's a nightmare if you want to complete 100%.

35471247.review:
Changed my mind. Yes, it is free but after some time it just turns into an annoying grind that repeats the same picture over and over and over and over again.

Current sample:
I had to visit the smithy twice at night. Now there are three modes and night mode is rare (or maybe it just feels that way because the two other modes look pretty similar) so you have to visit the smithy a lot to get the two night visits. When that one finished it immediately opened a quest to now visit the smithy four times during the day. Luckily the next four visits all were in day mode (illustrating the rarity of night mode). So now I get a quest to visit the dwarfen castle. To unlock it I need a medaillon which I only get from - again - the smithy. So one more visit.
These repeat visits wouldn't be so bad, BUT: to actually visit the smithy you each time need to bring two pieces of coal. Coal you only get from the stone quarry or the old town or that one monster whose weapon is the most expensive or the one box whose riddle I am not good at. Now doing any of those doesn't grant you a piece of coal. So you maybe need to visit one place 3-4 times to get one piece of coal. So for visiting the smithy one time you first have to visit the old town (lowest energy costs) 5-6 times for those two pieces of coal. I had to visit the smithy now 15 times in a row in quests which means I had to visit the stone quarry / old town about 100 times. Both areas are level 5 by now (even though my steam achievements don't show it) and they repeat the same few hidden object games. This is no challenge anymore. It's just boring. I know were every object is. The only good thing about it was that I now have so much building material that I immediately could repair the building producing a piece of coal every 8 hours. The only two building materials that I don't have enough are ropes and nails. Otherwise I could repair the entire island.

The only good thing to say is that it is free. But the whole way this game is designed is to encourage you to spend real money to move a bit forward. The 30 pieces of coal I needed for the 15 visits to the smithy would cost 30 crystals which in RL currency is 2,67€. And I really caught myself about thinking to spend this money just to escape every day looking at the same few things. Then I remembered that right after the coals there are the arrows I need to access another area and until I unlock it I don't yet know what I will need to actually access the dwarfen castle. So it's 3€ here and 3€ there until suddenly you have spend more on this free game than on games with a real story. 

Because that is another minus point. The story sucks. It was interesting at first but by now it is more like "hey, I have opened this zoo for animals so please go and catch this dragon or this fish, oh and each time you visit bring two pieces of meat". There was a time when meat was rare and I had troubles accessing the area, but because the old town also gives you meat I now would also have enough to visit that place 15 times. Also in those times of having troubles getting meat I repaired the slaughterhouse that gives you one piece of meat every 8 hours.

34667417.review:
ATTENTION : Bien qu'il s'appelle aussi Lost Lands, comme "Lost Lands : Mahjong", ce jeu n'a rien à voir avec les autres jeux du même nom des mêmes développeurs de FiveBN (Dark Overlord, The Four Horsemen, The Golden Curse). Il ne repose pas sur le même principe de jeu d'aventure mêlant point&click et énigmes.


C'est l'histoire d'une ville elfe qui vit en paix depuis des siècles quand un jour le mal s'abat sur elle sous la forme de nuages noirs. Les habitants désertent et parcourent les océans à la recherche d'un nouveau lieu de vie mais ils traversent d'impitoyables tempêtes dont seuls quelques survivants en réchappent et échouent sur une île déserte. Ils ont avec eux un sarcophage qui, selon la légende, renferme l'Elu qui saura sauver son peuple de sa terrible destinée le temps venu. C'est alors qu'il se réveille...

C'est après cette introduction que commence le jeu et on se retrouve avec à l'écran une vue aérienne sur un village dans ce qui ressemble à première vue à un petit jeu de stratégie ou de gestion de ressources.
On a un capital de pièces d'or et de cristaux, des points d'XP, un niveau, une jauge d'énergie. On a également accès à un grand inventaire divisés en plusieurs catégories (potion d'énergie, coffres, amulettes, clés, outils, armes).

Certains bâtiments du village sont inaccessibles car ils nécessitent d'atteindre au prélable un niveau minimum, d'autres peuvent être réparés/construits si on possède les objets requis et on peut explorer les autres si on a un niveau suffisant d'énergie.

L'exploration d'un lieu consiste en une SOC (avec liste de mots ou de silhouettes) en temps limité. On a des bonus à disposition en cas de besoin (indiquer un objet, dévoiler tous les objets ou bénéficier de temps supplémentaire). Plus on la termine rapidement, plus on gagne d'XP. Une fois complétée, on gagne un objet et le lieu passe un niveau d'amélioration.

Il s'agit donc bien de collecter divers objets, de gérer l'XP et l'argent à disposition et de débloquer progressivement de nouveaux lieux et de nouveaux objets. Il y a toute une liste de choses à trouver pour confectionner ou obtenir en échange d'autres artefacts. Il y a aussi la possibilité de faire des achats à la boutique selon notre budget à disposition.


Présenté comme ça, le jeu peut sembler sympa, surtout pour un titre gratuit. Mais une fois passées les premières minutes à découvrir le gameplay, c'est la douche froide!

On dépense de l'énergie lors de chaque action et elle ne peut être remontée que de 4 façons :
a) Avoir recours à une potion de  notre inventaire.
b) Utiliser les cristaux en notre possession pour acheter des potions à la boutique. Mais une fois dépensés les cristaux dont on dispose au départ, il faut forcément... dépenser de l'énergie pour en gagner d'autres....
c) Payer avec de l'argent réel !
d) Attendre que l'énergie remonte automatiquement et gratuitement. Lentement. Très lentement. Très très lentement.

Evidemment, nos potions sont vite consommées et nos cristaux entièrement dépensés. L'incitation à dépenser notre argent réel revient alors avec insistance (mais qui ferait ça?). Et attendre plus d'une heure à observer la jauge remonter avant de pouvoir faire une action et devoir attendre à nouveau... Pendant ce temps-là, il y a bien assez d'autres petits jeux sympathiques sur Steam pour passer de bon moment pour ne pas s'attarder avec celui-ci.



Donc c'est non, non et NON.

Thought it was a relatively good game, considering it's a free one.

[list]
[*]The levels are repetitive but fun. The same can be said for the "quests". It's good enough to waste a few minutes here and there.
[*]The nearly screen sized advertising to buy things using real money that pop up at every start up and every level up from level 5 and on could be easily ignored. And I can understand the creators wanting to gain something out of what they made.
[/list]

The reason I'm going to advise against playing this game is the problem I just got: The game seems to have "forgotten" who I was and started a new profile. And since you can't choose to do anything until after you have played a level and completed the first quest (I'm not kidding, you can't click anywhere other than where the tutorial want you to), that new profile seems to have replaced the one I had until now.

Now, granted, I wasn't that far along (LVL 8 and still the upper right and the bottom of the map hidden by the mist) but that's not the point. It happened to me, not a huge problem, since I didn't buy anything from the in game store, but what about if I had been one of those that can spend more per months in these kinds of game than the price of a new PC/PS4/XBoxOne game?

It might have been a problem with the game itself or with the steam cloud but the fact remains, there is no way to be sure if, after having gone nearly to the end and spend some real money in it, the next time you try to play it'll consider that you are a new player and make you start anew with nothing to show for it.

P.S.: And just because I know some will think it no, I didn't touch the options before the problem happened and the game was closed without any issue the previous time.

33299422.review:
This can become a pretty fun game if you are a patient sort of person.

This is a free game, so there is a pay system set up to help you play longer sessions and to aid you should you get stuck, but you never actually have to pay to fully enjoy the whole game.  As long as you don't mind putting in only a half hour once or twice a day and then moving on to something else, this game is fairly satisfying.

The artwork is beautiful and the story is engaging, there is plenty of variety in the hidden object scenes, and there is a fair amount of choice as far as what to do on the map which makes for a surprising strategy element to the game.  The chests have some fun little mini-games required to open them so that hidden object scenes are not the only puzzles you get to play.

It does take a few days or so to get the hang of how the game plays out, but as it is free to try, there is no reason not to give it a whirl and see if this title is for you.  If you do find you like this game check out their Lost Lands: Mahjong and Mystic Saga games as well.

33268320.review:
It's not a good game, but it's a decent time waster. A lot of people will probably get put off by the fact that you have to wait for you energy to refill before you can take an action, so you'll have to regularly revisit the game for relatively short amounts of time at a go to get anywhere. You can bypass this by investing actual coin in the game, which I guess is the point: having a game where you can plausibly make progress by putting a lot of time into it whilst at the same time not being so satisfying that you wouldn't not be tempted to throw money at it. Personally I felt that the game went a little bit over the line with pushing the money option. At one point I had about five limited time offers ticking away on my screen...

Beyond time wasting the game isn't exactly balanced. Progressing through the game you can unlock sixteen different hidden object game locations. These are challenging the first time or two, but after repeating them numerous times you get used to where the different objects are hidden, and they can easily be completed with full points and time to spare. Even the first few times mostly aren't that difficult because you amass plenty of 'tools' that will help you solve these puzzles. I even ended up using dozens of surplus tools [b]just[/b] so that I could get the tool use achievement.

In addition to the hidden object portion, there are also about seven different chest opening minigames with difficulties ranging from solve instantly/solve every time to pretty much impossible. There was one variety of minigame that most of the time I could only solve using a minigame skip tool (but you could also look up the solutions in the game guides on Steam). 

Probably my favourite part of the game was progressing through the story. With each location that you unlock a new character who will give you quests. Unfortunately you're only able to see these characters when they give you quests and for some reason, though most of the characters do have names, they're only tagged with their job/race descriptions (e.g. Hunter, Healer, Fairy, etc). I think that it would have been great if there was an in-game journal or cast page to give a bit more access to the flavour text side of things, otherwise it's just screencap it or forget it.

Really there's not much all the [i]objectionable[/i] about the game, but I would say that it's probably not worth the time that you need to invest in it. I wouldn't have invested so much time myself if not for the fact that I'd already invested plenty of time in it and wanted to see it through. ^_^;

33237725.review:
I wasn't really sure what to expect from a F2P hidden object adventure game, but it seems to be done fairly well. The objectives are easy to track, and the HO scenes get rearranged once you've done an area enough to level it up a couple of times. There are also variations to the scenes as well, which makes doing the same few scenes repeatedly in the early game more interesting than it sounds. The art and the music are both good as well.

Because it is a F2P game, it does have grinding elements and timers. So far in my play time I haven't really found the grinding to be punishing. Each scene location and each wandering enemy have specific rewards that you can get from them that are clearly listed. Additionally, when looking at the list of things you need for an objective, clicking on something you don't have will show you everywhere you can get that item. I've also found so far that rewards seem to prioritize items that you need for an objective. As for the timers, they don't seem particularly punishing either. You have an energy meter with the maximum amount of energy being determined by your level. Each scene and each enemy use a specified amount of energy and your energy slowly regenerates over time. Your energy also gets automatically refilled when you level up. While the regeneration of energy is rather slow, it's not unreasonable for a F2P game. If you don't want to pay for energy renewing items, you just need to do something else for a while and you'll have a full bar again.

Overall, I would recommend this to anyone who likes hidden object adventures and is fine with not being able to just blaze through everything in a sitting or two like most non-F2P HO games.

32476908.review:
Ein kostenloses Wimmelbildspiel, nach 32 Minuten wird man bereits zu Wartezeiten von mindestens 30 Minuten getrieben. Nach nun 4,3 Stunden hier die Pros und Kontras, gefolgt von einem kleinen Fazit:

Pro:
-Kostenlos (Mehr oder weniger)
-Wimmelbildspiel
-Sieht ganz nett aus
-Es gibt eine Story
-Beinhaltet auch kleine Minispiele
-Energie wieder voll bei Levelup
-Augenscheinlich viele Level und Maps
-Wimmelbilder werden schwerer je öfter man sie spielt
-Du kannst die Wartezeit durch das Umstellen der Rechnerzeit quasi skippen und die täglichen Boni schnell sammeln ohne Geld oder Zeit zu investieren... wow
-Geeignet für Leute mit 30-60 Minuten Zeit am Tag 

Kontra:
-32 Minuten Spielzeit bis zur ersten Wartezeit von mindestens 30 Minuten
-Wimmelbilder werden doppelt und dreifach gespielt, wahrscheinlich 100 fach im Verlauf des Spiels
-Wimmelbilder und Minigames haben eine zeitliche Begrenzung die sogar relativ knapp ist (Aber nach 7 mal der gleichen Map weiß man wo alles liegt)
-Level werden schwerer, kosten aber gleichzeitig auch um einiges mehr Energie
-Dauernd Werbung und "Schnäppchen" Angebote für PayItems und Truhen
-Es dauert wirklich ewig bis man Rohstoffe für Questorte oder extra Energie gesammelt hat, da die benötigte Menge an Rohstoffen sehr hoch ist und aus einem Wimmelbild auch keine Duplikate gewonnen werden können
-Level-Up und damit das Freischalten von neuen Wimmelbildern dauert ewig
-Eine Quest damit man das Spiel frühzeitig bewertet, bevor es wirklich anfängt nervig zu werden
-Die Story ist quasi unmerklich bei der Zeit, die verstreicht, bis man mal zum nächsten Storystück kommt
-Energie-Regenerationsrate verringert sich mit Level ups? Anfangs 2 Minuten, jetzt bereits 5 für einen Energiepunkt bei einem Maximum von 150 (150*5)/60=12,5 Stunden um den Balken voll zu bekommen. 
-Schamloser Cashgrab
-RICHTIG schamloser Cashgrab

Fazit:
Extrem langwieriger und langweiliger Tablet-Wimmelbild-Kram mit vielleicht 45 Minuten Spielzeit pro Tag. Mal abgesehen von der zeitlichen Begrenzung in den Wimmelbildern und Minispielen gibt es quasi keine Herausforderung. Man klickt vielleicht 5-10 Wimmelbilder pro voller Energieleiste durch und sammelt in den ewig selben Maps die gleichen Items und bekommt dann zufällig Rohstoffe, die man dutzendfach braucht um die Wartezeiten marginal zu verkürzen. Währenddessen wird irgendwo eine Story erzählt, die man aber leider bei der ganzen Wartezeit schnell wieder vergisst. Irgendwas mit einem Elfenkönig der von der Insel runter will? Ja irgendwas in die Richtung war es. Nur was für Leute die viel Geduld und sonst alle Wimmelbildspiele auf Steam durchgespielt haben, alternativ nur was für Menschen die gerne Geld für Müll bezahlen wollen. 

#Extratipp
Einfach, wenn die Energieleiste leer ist, das Datum in eurem Windows um einen Tag nach vorne Stellen und schon könnt ihr weiter machen. Schreibt euch aber das aktuelle Datum irgendwo auf Jungs und Mädels.

Es ist kein Spiel für stundenlanges Am-Stück-Spielen - der Haken ist, daß man "Energie" benötigt, die sich entweder langsam mit der Zeit oder per Kauf-Items aus dem ingame-Shop auffüllt.

Das Spiel an sich besteht hauptsächlich aus Rätselbildern in der Art "Finde x Gegenstände in einem überladenen Bild" und gelegentlichen Minipuzzles, um Kisten zu öffnen, verpackt in einer Queststory mit Suchaufgaben.

31938705.review:
This is an adventure game with a story that unfolds as you complete certain goals by playing minigames to earn various items. The story serves mainly to introduce missions, and lacks much entertainment value.

Hidden Object minigames are the most prominent feature. A scene can be played as many times as you want. The first time is usually impossible to beat, but it gets easier as you become familiar with it. Playing these scenes earns you items which are required to complete quests and unlock new areas. Finding a treasure chest allows you to play a different minigame with logical elements, to unlock the chest.

The hidden object scenes are weak in content compared to others I've played, and are more challenging due to the short time you have to finish.

This game uses a facebook-type energy system which forces you to quit after completing a certain number of actions, and wait until your energy replenishes over time. This makes the game enormously frustrating because you can't play as long as you want. Also, I find this game is hard on the eyes.

Despite its shortcomings, the game draws you in and is easy to come back to for repeated plays.

If you've ever played a facebook game, then you should know what to expect.

31780399.review:
To be honest, this is another occasion where I wish Steam had a "meh" button, since that is how this game has left me feeling. It's not horrible, but it's not great either. It is free, thank goodness, and it's an ok time waster, however the energy system leaves a LOT to be desired. You will average about 4 hidden object scenes before you are out of energy; give or take a few depending on how far you have maxed out your energy bar. I think my biggest gripe about this game, though, is that the hidden object scenes are timed...yep, you read that correctly...they...are...timed. Now, from what I've gathered about most of us HOG players, we don't really want to be rushed. Add to that the fact that the graphics aren't so great, and some of the items you are looking for are TINY, well, it turns into a bit of a rushed, not so fun adventure. 

PROS:
*Storyline
*FREE ( best pro ever :) )
*Different types of HOG's (Silhouettes, Night-time, etc.)
*More than just HOG's ( puzzles, quests, non-combat monster kills, etc.)

CONS:
*Energy System
*Timed Hidden Object and Puzzle scenes
*Hard to find objects in the Hidden Object scenes ( could just be my computer, as I'm on a laptop, but I can't discount it.)
*Too much hand-holding during the tutorial, including making you spend hints and blue gems (premium currency) with no way to opt out

All in all, it's a free game folks, so if you can get past the fact that you will only play around 10- 15 minutes at a time ( for free) then it's not all that bad. I will continue playing to see if my mind changes, but at this point I'm going to have to stick with a Not Recommended, mainly for the timed scenes, no way to bypass the energy system ( like letting us pay an amount to "buy" the game) and most of all, the tutorial that forced me to spend a hint and premium currency...that's a no-no in my book. It should be up to the player whether they need that much of a tutorial or not, thank you very much developers. If you don't mind any of these things, and just want a short time waster, then you have nothing to lose...it's FREE!

31670157.review:
It's your everyday scammy mobile-like puzzle game using the hidden object mechanics to its adventage. It has some other puzzles as well (and they are quite a lot of fun!), nevertheless it's the same story you hear in other games like this: to play you need energy, to get energy you need to wait, if you don't want to wait - you have to buy in-game currencies. 

As in many cases, it's actually a really fun game... when you can play it (and for the first couple of hours you can play it for quite a long time without many pauses, what can get addicting). But for most of the time, you can spend on it only a couple of minutes and then wait half a day or even a day before you can play again. The game obviously uses a lot of mechanisms trying to lure you into buying additional energy, but you would have to spend hundreds of dollars to actually get to the end of the game.

The main problem I have is the endgame. The costs of making various actions get insane and dice rolls such as "will I get an item I'm looking for?" are getting crucial and unpleasant. The most annoying part are the missions such as "explore area X 5 times during a night". But since the game never lets you know if it's a night or a daytime, it, again, is just a bunch of frustrating rolls and misses. 

It could have been a fantastic game if it would be redesigned into a single 10-20 USD purchase and would let you play as long as you want.

But since it's freemium and uses all the bs freemium mechanics designed to make a profit out of 5% of the playerbase, it constantly suffers from the needless limitations. 

I didn't get to the end of the game. I got bored.

Even though the core story idea was pretty fun, silly but self-conscious as well. And it had some beautiful graphics. I just couldn't take it anymore.

30708727.review:
This is a damn beautiful game. The object/character/background art is really top notch. There's an in-depth plot, and missions queuing up constantly to guide you through it.  Really, above and beyond for a hidden object game. I like the building experience points and correlating difficulty of the game, and i love the collections required to repair things/get things done. I do NOT like that I just started playing twenty minutes ago, and I'm constantly running out of energy (points needed to play a level). Couple that with the fact that I need diamonds, not gold, to buy items to replenish energy, and it makes me think I won't play this game much more. There doesn't seem to be a way to convert my seemingly-useless gold into diamonds, so I'm supposed to spend real money on them, or wait for my energy to replenish?? There are so many facets of this game that are incremental that work to enrich the experience, but having an energy bar isn't one of them. It replenishes so slowly over time, it seems the point is to turn the game off. I understand that I'll get rewards for coming back day after day, but I'd really appreciate playing for a more than a half hour at a time. 

So in reality it seems this "Free-to-play" game should be labeled "Pay-to-play", if you have more of an attention span than a ten year old. Or the developers could put a real price on it ($5, maybe $10? The art really is fucking fantastic) and scratch the energy bar dynamic completely.

30667360.review:
While Lost Lands doesn't have the best environment art or the most challenging puzzles and searches I have experienced in a hidden object game, it does interest me with a much longer playing experience than I would normally expect from this genre.

The stamina system is not particularly forgiving but after some quick early levels, you will be able to run several adventures each session. If you don't like to wait to play, regenerative boosts are fairly easy to obtain.

The character art is very appealing and even has a bit of movement and resolution manipulation to make them look more interesting. The town map keeps things in perspective and there is a lot of stuff to do.

The shop nearly turned me away when I first looked into it but after a couple of hours, I have nearly forgotten it is even there.

I am looking forward to spending some time exploring another game in one of my favorite genres.

It's quite fun at first - even the energy system (limiting how often you can "explore", i.e. play the HOG) isn't so bad.

However, once you reach the point where you have to basically pray to the gods of RNG that finally, this time, maybe, hopefully you'll get the right game mode to continue with the only quest you currently have, is rather annoying.

Especially since you don't really have keys for that location and have to play other areas just to farm that key.

Put in words: Play the "town" area about 2 times to get 1 key to "mage tower". Play "mage tower" probably 5-who-knows-how-many-times to get "night mode" in "mage tower".
Repeat 4 times to complete the quest.
Remember: you can perhaps play 4 areas until you run out of energy - unless you found energizers beforehand you have to spend crystals (found, or bought) or wait several hours.

So you're stuck doing the same two locations for days. Not fun. Not at all.

If there were more quests, so you could just do them as you go along, that'd be fine. But just one quest, where you have to happen to come across the right game mode - a game mode that's rather rare already (and not much fun either) - that's where I quit and uninstalled the game.

Go ahead and try it, all it'll cost you is time, after all.

I love hidden object games, and have played enough of them to know what a good one is like. While this game has some potential, there is a lot of room for improvement.

Pros: Story line is pretty decent. 

Cons: Each time you explore an area, you use energy, and a large amount of it. You either have to wait several hours for it to replenish or spend money to buy more. The amount of time you are given to explore an area is only 1 minute. This is not enough time to find hidden objects, especially if the graphics aren't that great. If you are zoomed out of a picture, they graphics are nice, but when you zoom in to locate a hard to find object, the graphics become pixelated and somewhat distorted. Also, when you find a chest, you only have a very limited amount of time to solve a puzzle to open it. 

Overall: Game play time is limited and you almost feel rushed to complete puzzles and hidden object areas.

A wonderful game to waste some time! 29235143.review:
Perfekte Ergänzung zu Lost Lands: Mahjong . Für alle die Wimmelbildergames mögen, ist es zu empfehlen. Da man auch unter Zeitdruck steht um an die "Sterne" zu kommen, hat es auch keinen Easy Going Charakter. Energie für die Runden sind ebenso begrenzt. Jedoch füllt sich die Energie stets auf. Hat man genügend Gegenstände gesammelt kann man Bonusmaterial erhalten, sodass man sein Spiel aufpeppt mit: Rasche Energieaufladung, Waffen, Münzen und vieles mehr zum Entdecken!

ACHTUNG: Kostenfalle wenn man reinkippt: Man kann jederzeit Energie und Equipment gegen Barbezahlung nachkaufen. Ansonsten sind beide Spiele (Hidden Obj. und Mahjong) absolut kostenlos. 

Es ist ein Gelegenheitsspiel im wahrsten Sinne des Wortes  (sowie auch die Free to Play Mahjong Version)  und ab und zu muss man eben wenn man nicht unnötig Geld ausgeben möchte, 12 bis 24 Stunden aussetzten um wieder kräftig ein paar Runden zu spielen.  Je höher man mit dem Game Level steigt, desto teurer werden auch die Energiekosten die man braucht um "eine Runde" weiterzukommen.

Illustrationen sind sehr gut gelungen. Nette Graphik  und gute Sounds bekräftigen meine Weiterempfehlung.

This game is not worth your time. You will run out of crystals pretty soon, and you can only buy cristals for real money and it is expensive. 26738967.review:
This game is one in which you either have to pay as you play (to easily access more of the game) or wait and plod along VERY slowly. By that I mean- in the time it will take to unlock achievements (in free to play - and probably even pay to play) you could have instead been able to have finished a long game of say: Assassins Creed or a Final Fantasy game (including the extras/bonuses)! So - it's laid out like a casual game - but if you're hoping to unlock achievements it becomes more of a time waster and the opposite of a casual game. It can literally take about 50 hours to unlock just one of the achievements- check out the global statistics to see how many people noped out of completing the game because of the crazy amount of game play you have to wrack up to feel like you've achieved anything. And the extra elements of new locations aren't quite unique enough to keep you interested by that point.

But if you love hidden objects games and find a lot of them too short for you this can be your answer to that- as this game is pretty much impossibly long considering how simple it is. I'd recommend checking out a steam walkthrough for some of the treasure chest puzzles (as some are a lot more difficult than others)  and maybe a walkthrough on how to best make use of your energy so you can be smarter about how you use it.

It's games like these that make you wish there was a 'maybe recommend' button instead of yes or no. Similar to other games by this group they are designed to take a long time to fully complete - but in the end I would probably say a storyline based RPG would be much more engaging than spending time on this game. Get out while you still can :O - like Candy Crush this is designed to look like a simple casual game but it just doesn't seem to end.

POSITIVES:
* A hidden objects game that you won't find too short.
* At first with the energy limitations it's paced out slowly enough that you won't get bored straight away.

NEGATIVES:
* It tries to have a storyline but I'm unsure if it's even possible to get an ending because by the way it looks it seems like you'd need to get 150 hours of gameplay to get there. This game truly tests your patience.
* Way too long to unlock accomplishments- they could have cut down the requirements by a third and it would be engaging and challenging, as opposed to a sadistic plod.
* Life is too short to spend crazy amounts of time on a game that won't offer enough change and storyline to make it worth it.
* The game follows patterns to make it addictive (rare drops, limited energy) instead of dynamic/exciting.

26585619.review: QUITS WORKING IF YOU DON'T MAKE IN-GAME PURCHASES. As a supposed 'free' game that requires 'in-game' purchases it is clear that the developers of this game don't want people to play if they're not willing to spend money. Ironically, I'd be fine purchasing this game for a few dollars outright--but I absolutely won't get sucked into spending money on an ongoing basis simply for a hidden object game. And, after a few days of play, it is obvious that the developers of this game  have coded it in such a way that if you don't spend money, eventually you stop getting credit for your game play. You can still 'play' but you can't progress. As of day 4, I stopped getting credit for any solved 'quests'. I thought it was just a temporary glitch. As of day 5, when I logged in, the daily bonus counter said that now I was only on 'day 2' and gave me bonuses only for that day - even though the day before I had been on day 4.  Finally, I should've known better and been wary about any game whose nerdy and clearly socially inept developers designed the images of women so they look like something right out of a porn movie. Clearly the creators of this game are very likely strong misogynists, who only view women based on their looks, very likely have never been on a date, and probably still live in their parents' basements.

25002793.review:
Pay2Play + Wimmelbild. Alles geht auf Zeit, alle Resourcen sind unangenehm knapp. Ich würde lieber einmal Vollpreis zahlen als alle halbe Stunde das Spiel unterbrechen zu müssen, weil der Aktionspunktebalken sich erstmal wieder ein paar Stunden aufladen muss. Auch grafisch erinnert es stark an ein Browserspiel.

Zum Spiel selbst. Zu Anfang nervt der Zeitbalken in den Wimmelbildszenen sehr, man hat nicht die Muße, die Szene zu studieren und einfach mal Gegenstände für eine spätere Rückkehr zur selben Szene zu identifizieren. Das legt sich schnell, denn man wird immer wieder zu den selben Wimmelbildern geschickt und kennt bald die meisten Gegenstände. Ab dem fünften Besuch oder so hilft das Zeitlimit, die Spielspannung zu erhalten.

Wie in einem Pay2Play Browserspiel führt man eine scheinbar endlose Questreihe aus und schaltet langsam weitere Orte und Bereiche der Karte frei.

Wenn man nicht regelmäßig ein paar Stunden unterbrechen müsste, weil mal wieder der Aktionspunktebalken leer ist, wäre das Spiel durchaus unterhaltsam. So rate ich vom Kauf ab, der Frustfaktor ist einfach zu groß.

24999453.review:
No lo jugué cuando aún no estaba en castellano, ahora cuando ya implantaron el idioma, empecé a jugarlo, aunque poco, porque no me permite jugar más tiempo sin pagar. 

Las EOO en concreto no duran mucho, de hecho están cronometradas todas. Hay constantes misiones que cumplir y objetos que reparar para poder desbloquear más escenarios y cumplimentar misiones. 

El puzzle para poder abrir los cofres es siempre EL MISMO, con diferentes variantes, los objetos a buscar en el mismo escenario, se repiten. 

Desbloquear escenarios y encontrar objetos para reparar lo que está roto y a su vez poder desbloquear más escenarios es bastante díficil porque siempre depende de la energía que tengas, del mismo modo ocurre con el puzzle para abrir los cofres que encuentras, enseguida entras en bucle y o dejas de jugar o pagas.

De la misma forma, tienes un tope de tiempo/energía para jugar diariamente, bastante bajo, por cierto.

El juego en sí no está mal, aunque para mi gusto es mucho ruido y pocas nueces, hay que dar muchísimas vueltas para poder al final ir al mismo escenario a encontrar los mismos objetos que ya has encontrado anteriormente varias veces.

Entiendo que es un juego FREE TO PLAY y que el único ingreso que tiene son los micropagos y reconozco que éstos no son elevados, así que no me puedo quejar porque no me deje jugar sin pagar porque de eso se trata, pero creo que está mal pensado, no tienes ninguna opción de "engancharte" al juego antes de plantearte empezar a soltar €, al final me aburro y lo dejo. 

Sinceramente, no sé si recomendarlo o no, ya he dicho que no es mal juego, pero sin pagar tienes poca libertad y poco que hacer.

Lost Lands is a game that grabed my interest and desire to play and continue to play. I like the concept of collecting the different materials form the HOG areas and characters in the game that help to repair certain areas on the island, completing quests, and doing the mini games for opening the chests.  It is also a great game to play if you have only a limited time to play, about 20-30min to play at a time every 5-6hrs, through out the day. As different areas are repaired it does decrease the time needed to build up energy points and the amount of energy points that can be rebuilt.

Negatives are it takes a while to rebuild enough energy points to explore areas and open chests.  Another negative is that when you move up in levels, which opens new areas to explore, it requires certain items to unlock these areas. Most of these items require chrystals to get them.  Chrystals are only occassionally given in very limited quantities (as level up or based on number of continuous days played) so have to use cash to purchae the chrystals or not get the item and have only limited HOG areas to explore.

The game would be even better if there were new updates or quests to complete.

24483683.review:
[h1]...эта история началась очень давно, но кто бы ее не сказывал, первым упоминанием в ней всегда были эльфы...[/h1]

И все бы ничего, коль остроухие уходили сразу в никуда, но кто ж им позволит? Вот и приходится выручать самих себя, а заодно устраивать пикники с поиском предметов в каждой левой [strike]мусорке[/strike] локации. Стоит ли говорить, что все придет в итоге в норму?

Скорее нет, чем да, поскольку история еще не закончена, а обновления выходят не так чтобы уж слишком часто. Знаете, однако, что мне понравилось? Да, рисовка красивая, локации здоровские, персонажи доставляют - одна [strike]Полумна Лавгуд[/strike] спасенная эльфийка чего стоит, да и рыбак - смесь Волкодава с Геральтом из Ривии - но их незамысловатая история и квесты (не все, но некоторые), призваны лишь на подольше удержать в своих лапах беспечных игроков. А квестов тут действительно очень много, и вряд ли без доната (hiden object + донат = страшная штука) вы сможете быстро одолеть основную историю, а ведь еще есть линия-продолжение за сына ГГ главной линии сюжета...

Сразу стоит оговориться, что идти сюда ради достижений или недолгого времяпрепровождения - затея глупая, ведь тут как с кликерами - приходи раз в день, трать что возможно, приходи через сутки, снова трать и так до бесконечности. Достижения того не стоят, геймплей поиска скрытых объектов вас убьет - на одну и ту же локацию, Хижину в лесу, к примеру (вспомнили фильм, а?)), вы будете ходить не только в начале игры, а ВСЮ игру. Ну там, лут привязанный к локации получить, уровень мастерства локации повысить... Все в этом духе. Вас хватит на эту игру только если вы пример терпеливости и времени у вас - вагон и тележка с ведром. 

В общем, я вас предупредил. Сюжет, кстати, не так плох, как кажется поначалу. Просто разбавлен подчас дурацкими квестами, а в остальном - всё не так уж и плохо. Но черт возьми, я хочу эту эльфийку, что стала владелицей собственного зверинца фантастических существ (О_О)

24374591.review:
The game is pretty well done. Nice graphics, good atmosphere, sound, everything looks well, so why the negative rating?

Personally I don't like to see the intrusion of the agressive merchandising from the mobile market into the PC games, and this is exactly what it is. It plays like a standard mobile game, whith pay to advance because of timelocks and shameless advertising.

I would rather pay a full price and then I could recommend it, but not if a vendor tries to get micropayents just to keep playing. And considering how fast you get stopped you can't really say there is much gameplay, because you play a few clicks and then you wait a few hours, wihch gets even worse, because finding the objects is done with a clock ticking, so you have only a short time. After you replay the same scene again (which you have to do freuquently) it becomes even harder, because you wont see the full screen anymore. Just a small area that you canmove around. So combined with the time pressure and the small number of playing minutes you should check yourself (it's free after all). Personally I can't recommend it, because it takes the fun out of it.

24029354.review: Lost Lands: A Hidden Object Adventure is a supposed-to-be-free game. You can install it with no cost but if you want to play it regularly, it becomes costy. My objection is not the Pay-toWin nature of the game, but the game itself. It looks like a Facebook app rather than a standalone game. You have an energy bar which decreases when you make a movement. During the playtime you will see both mini puzzles (I have only seen 1 type in my playtime) and some hidden object scenes (multiple visit to the same area, very repetitive). You must finish your tasks in a short time period. For me, the time limis was the most annoying part of the game. I like HOGs because of the absence of the time limits, pacey gameplay etc.

24004981.review:
I only played this game for 15 minutes and that was enough for me to know that this wasnt for me. 

You have a energy bar that fills up with time and depletes when you play, much like a facebookgame. You pay microtransactions to fill it up so you dont have to wait and bla bla bla, you know the drill. 

The thing that makes me feel like this was a bad game was the timelimit on the quests. I enjoy hidden object games because I think its calming and a nice break from all the other, faster games I play. But in this game you have a time limit to finish each map, wich in my opinion defeats the purpose of a hidden object game. 

The images are beautiful and I have no time to enjoy them cause I have to find the hidden objects before the time limit reaches the end. I dont feel like I get the calming break cause I feel stressed out to finish the maps in time. If you like that, give it a try, its free to play, but for me it was completly wrong.

23660165.review:
As a FREE hidden object game, I liked it very much to start. There are lots of quests and areas to unlock to keep things interesting as you level up. The hidden objects themselves are not very difficult to find, though. Annoyingly, I can only play a few minutes a day due to having to use energy for each action. Of course you can purchase potions and things to extend your energy (microtransactions). I can ignore and forgive that because the game is free. HOWEVER, when I logged in one day after 15 hours of ten-minutes-at-a-time gameplay, my game was RESET TO LEVEL 1! At this point, it doesn't matter if it is free - it's no fun to play a game that disrespects the time you've put into it and forces you to start from scratch.

If the energy limitations, microtransactions, and spirit-deflating bug were removed, this would be a really fun casual game.

23516491.review:
About this game: It's free
It's a hidden object game
It does not have silly: you click on things too fast and you get kicked from playing ("continuous playing)
The objects are nicely hidden, for the first 5 plays in a level anyway
The objects change nicely (not in levels, but through levels: Example, bow starts as a weapon, then changes to a birthday ribbon in later levels. 
It is rather relaxing, on higher levels, since, everything is done, and everything needs doing (achievements take 3 years to complete) (actually, I finished them, so a 100 hours to finish the game free.)
I think the quests were sometimes rather fun (story wise, going to a night mission 4 times is just...brainnumbing)
All the little enemies keep popping up, making a lively game.

downsidey: Whenever you get a chest, it opens up a special window, you need to close, extremely bothersome
Each and every game opening brings you to a buy all our games, or you will get this commercial again and again commercial, it doesn't help.
Perfect placement of cancel button on roaming creatures, and open chest, that suddenly pops up :S
No double use of relics. You want the double energy for a day to prolong? not going to happen, wait out the entire day!
Every level nets you an offer to pay 10 bucks for useless items, that stays on for 24 hours.
Achievements are terrible, not just LOOOOOOOOOOOONG, but also, completely spaced out. Finished all the area's. Now go kill 150 out of the required 200 kills on each monster.
(reading the last few reviews also: The game is a little bit easy. as in: When I finished the entire game, I had once actually managed to time out a hidden object scene. Also, there are many "helpful" things, such as hints to where things are. They build up fast, since you don't need them (but they have achievements, so just click on use anyway, since...dumb achievements)
All items have the uncanny ability to take some time popping up. Chests give you time to click on another creature, then when you try to cancel them, open the chest instead, certain items that find objects for you, are "wasted" because you click on it and all items it found the first item use, are mysteriously still in transit and "found again". You're basically waiting more for the animation of items to finish and stop cluttering up your screen, then you are waiting for energy.

Basically, too commercialised, so happy I finished all the achievements and can now click on delete local saves!

I do enjoy the game, and it has a lot going for it. The puzzles encourage the hidden object finding, and unlocking all the areas is fun. 

However, I'm to a point where I need some items to unlock certain areas, and either I have to pay to get "gems" or I have to wait until one of these items suddenly appears from random locations. There is nothing telling you which location these items might be located at either. (the devs have answered this problem with "just be patient, eventually it will drop." They said it shows where it drops, but it does not.)

I would gladly pay an unlock fee ($4.99 or so in order to remove the energy bar) but I'm not paying for gems, a resource that will just run out and then I'll have to get more. And because it's structured like that I can't recommend it. 

Add a paid version and I will recomend. But I'm not going to recommend a freemium game.

23141178.review:
A game where you have to wait for energy to use in order to play,
Completing a game of Hidden Objects within a limited time you will be reward you with random items which are used to complete collections, unlock new areas and complete quests.
It’s highly repetitive and the stories are pointless (you really don’t need to read a single word in the game.)
The quests are the same things over and over, find certain items, play a certain area or interact with the creatures walking around the world map.

You’re constantly shown "offers" of micro-transactions.

Achievements are a massive grind, you will have to repeat some parts up to 200 times and there’s very little variation between most of them.

Purely just a cash grab for anyone gullible enough to make the in-game purchases.
If you want free achievements then go for it, that's the only good thing I can say about this game if you like collecting them but expect some of them to take a long time.

23133229.review:
Fakten: Die Wimmelbilder sind auf Zeit, häufige Wiederholungen der gleichen Bilder, für jedes Bild muss man von seinem in Echtzeit auffüllenden Energiekonto zahlen, gratis kann man nur kurze Zeit spielen, dann ist das Energiekonto leer, Auffüllen gegen echtes Geld.

Wenn man diese Fakten akzeptiert und entweder laufend echtes Geld investiert oder sich einfach damit arrangiert, dass man den ganzen Tag immer wieder für ein paar Minuten spielen kann, dann ist das ein nettes Spielchen für zwischendurch.

Vorteil: Das Spiel sorgt dafür, dass man nicht ewig weiterspielt. Genau richtig für das kleine Spielchen vor dem Schlafengehen.

It's a free-to-play hidden object game, which is more fit for your mobile computer- sorry, "phone," than your laptop or stationary. Still, it's not bad or broken by any means, and while it offers microtransactions they're hardly necessary to play the game. So if you're just looking to slay some time and have grown bored of Solitare, try this out. It's not like you have anything to lose.

Also, I noticed that there's another game similar to this, only you play mahjong instead of looking for hiden objects. And apart from the gameplay, it's practically identical to this one; it's got the same graphics, the same story, and the same collection system, only you play mahjong instead... I can't really fault anyone here though, it's a free-to-play franchise, and the similarities don't take away from the actual gameplay. I just felt I needed to point it out. *shrug*

22808188.review:
Schönes Free to Play Game!

Also diesmal wird meine Review relativ kurz ausfallen, da es nicht viel zu sagen gibt.
Das Spiel ist ein Wimmelbildspiel das wie ein Social Media Spiel funktioniert: Man hat eine bestimmte Menge an Energie und wenn diese verbraucht ist, kann man nicht mehr weiterspielen.
Mit Diamanten kann man sich neue Energie kaufen, sind die Diamanten aufgebraucht bekommt man entweder welche durch ein Level Up oder man kauft sich welche mit Echtgeld.

Bisher, nach knapp 3 Std. spielen bin ich noch nicht der Meinung, dass man sich zwingend Diamanten mit Echtgeld kaufen sollte. Man sollte sich täglich ca 1 bis 2 mal Mindestens anmelden um groß weiterzukommen, aber das stört nicht.

Für ein einfaches, kostenloses Spiel ist das schön gemacht, tolle Musik und schöne Grafik. 
Man Wimmelt auf Zeit, aber man muss immer wieder die selben Gegenstände finden und nach einer Zeit hat man sich die Position der Gegenstände auch eingeprägt.

Zwischendurch findet man auch verschlossene Kisten und Schatullen, die man nur durch knifflige Rätsel öffnen kann.

Fazit: Für ein Free to Play Spiel ganz gut gemacht. Ein nettes Spiel für zwischendurch mit guten Rätseln und schöner Grafik.

22734798.review:
TL/DR : Fun little game to kill a few minutes while you're bored with other games and want a change of pace.

Don't go into this thinking you'll be able to play this for hours on end.  Like all energy based games, patiences is the key.  Following are a few tips that may be usefull :

[u]Cash Items[/u]
If you want to spend money on it (wich is fine, devs gotta live, right?), I'd recommend the hint giving item so you learn every object location in every stage. [strike]There seem to be about two image placement type per location.[/strike]  Playing the game this way will help you build your memory, and speed up your process.  Avoid spending money on energy as it replenish over time and at level-up.  Your energy also increase by 10 at each level-up.  There are a few structures that act as free level-up, or that decrease the energy cooldown.
(edit : my bad, more then two item placement layout, but those come later when you "level-up" a location.  the number is still fixed so initial comment still hold.)
(edit : when I mean speed up you process, I mean it... actual locations take a few tens of seconds at most when you get around to it)

[u]Play regularly, but briefly[/u]
Play this three times a day (morning, lunch and evening), or more if you have the time, then switch to something else while your energy build back up. There are also structures you may repair that will yield various bonus (experience, energy, building materials, chest, etc) after a specific amount of time.

[u]Be smart about leveling-up[/u]
Leveling up fully refill your energy (anyone is getting the MAA feeling yet?).  It may be good to delay (waiting on quest rewards) or speed up (kill a few mobs) your leveling depending on your remaining energy and/or time left to play.

[u]Did someone say puzzle?[/u]
One of the best part of the game are the chests. They also need a small amout of energy to use, but unlike location, the cost does not increase with continuous success. They will contain various type of loot depending on the type.  The puzzles (mini-game) involved in opening them are fun and all involve spatial cognition, such as : linking dots of various color without crossing them, moving stones to let something through, linking gems with a beam of light, etc.  They are somewhat easy, but made more challenging by the time limit you have.

[u]Loot[/u]
If you understand the basics of the game, including leveling up locations (they will give one additional drop per level, up to +5 from the basic 1... at least that's my guess for now), you'll find it's not that grindy of a game.  Use the structures and log in reapedly briefly (as stated above) to maximize your profit.

[u]A word on achievement[/u]
Yes, they seem to be more difficult to get then it's Mahjong counterpart.  But would you rather have 100% of easy achievements (that everyone have)?  Or a few rares ones?

22589627.review:
Kostenlos hin oder her, so wie es jetzt ist, würde ich das Spiel nicht weiterempfehlen. Nicht nur das langsame Aufladen der Energie (wovon man im späteren Spiel immer mehr braucht) und die daraus resultierende immer längere Wartezeit zum vervollständigen der Aufgaben, sondern die inzwischen auch ziemlich aufdringliche Werbung beim Starten des Spiels und auch im Spiel selbst stören mich doch erheblich. Das Ganze hätte man anders lösen können, aber nun ja….

Das Spiel an sich finde ich persönlich schön gemacht; man befindet sich auf einer Insel und kann erst nur einige wenige Orte erforschen, bis man nach einigen Quests weitere Orte freischalten kann. Dazu spawnen auch nach und nach verschiedene Monster auf der Karte, die man mit speziellen Waffen ‚bekämpfen‘ kann. Auch kann man Truhen finden und durch ein kleines Minispiel öffnen.
Man bekommt mit der Zeit verschiedene Items für das Erforschen von Orten, durch das Besiegen von Monstern oder indem man Truhen öffnet. Mit diesen Items kann man wiederum Sammlungen vervollständigen (ist auch des Öfteren mal eine Questaufgabe) und bekommt Belohnungen in Form von Gold, Erfahrungspunkten und/oder diversen Gegenständen, die einem das Spiel für kurze Zeit erleichtern.

Leider kostet Orte erforschen und Truhen öffnen Energie, und das nicht zu knapp. Dazu erhöht sich der Bedarf an benötigter Energie jeweils um 5, je öfter man einen Ort erforscht. Die Quests, die man lösen muss, beinhalten dann auch noch Aufgaben wie „Erforsche diesen Ort fünf Mal“ oder „Besiege dieses Monster zehn Mal“. Dann heißt es warten, bis sich die benötigte Energie wieder aufgeladen hat, was allerdings nur sehr langsam passiert (ca. 20 Energiepunkte in einer Stunde).

Es gibt natürlich auch Gegenstände, die die Energie zumindest zum Teil wieder aufladen können, jedoch sind diese nicht gerade leicht zu bekommen und kosten als Ingame-Währung Kristalle. Davon bekommt man bei einem Levelaufstieg 5, und wenn man sich brav täglich einloggt, nach den ersten fünf Tagen 6 (danach alle sieben Tage). Und natürlich kann man sich die Kristalle dann auch für echtes Geld kaufen, wenn man denn gewillt ist.

Ansonsten heißt es warten, bis man wieder genügend Energie zusammen hat, um die nächste Aufgabe zu lösen…

The Hidden Object premise gets a brilliant twist in the form of a lite-adventure game. Beautiful artwork, terrific and engaging soundtrack, and clever dressings over fetch-quests set this edition apart from most of its peers. 
However, gorgeous surface or not, it does suffer from the grating necessity of "energy management", the annoying mechanic that impedes progress and immersion with sloggish downtime to regenerate enough mana to continue onwards. All the trappings of a mobile for-profit game are here, with only the most pleasing of eye candy to entice players into the trap. 
Still, great concept and addictive new variations on HOG mechanics make it at least an ejoyable pastime, if not a full tilt adventure commitment.

22541460.review:
Hidden objects games should let any type of player spend as much time as they'd like completing a puzzle.  I understand the point of having achievements (thus the 3 stars being on a time limit), but I highly disagree with the player losing completely once the time goes down.  It encourages random clicking along the screen, while making it near impossible for players to look around and also enjoy the art and environment your artsists and designers so lovingly created.  

Certain people will always have trouble finding specific objects, until they have begun to recognize and memorize how the objects look.  However, this method greatly punishes new players of this game or genre, while inducing panic in players that might enjoy spending as much time as they like.  I like the art, and the story, and the somewhat integration of resource management, but you don't let all player types play the game as they want.  You don't let players take their time in a game that challenges the mind.  If you did that, you would gain even more fans of this game.

22371786.review:
Lost Lands: A Hidden Object Adventure is based on the universe of Lost Lands, a hidden object adventure series set in another dimension or I suppose so because the games are done by the same people, with the same title. However, here, you take in your hands the destiny of the Elven Nation, crashed on a lost island, rebuilding their civilization and ready to set sail elsewhere if only a magical storm wasn't preventing them to do so.

This is the first free-to-play released by Five-BN. The second one, Lost Lands: Mahjong, shares the same story, the same quests and the same mechanics. It means that apart the core gameplay (hidden objects - mahjong), nothing changed when the second was released. I've played Mahjong first because I love the solitaire version of this game and A Hidden Object Adventure came after. It also means that the majority of this review will be identical to the one I did for Mahjong.

The gameplay itself is to find objects in different locations: a list of words, a list of shapes, with also a cycle of day and night as some quests required a "night", in other words, the scene will be only partially visible, as if you were carrying a torch. Generally, the scenes can be done easily, even if objects are changing places. It's pretty rare to be out of time.

Quests, while needing explorations for anything (weapons, tools, ressources, etc..), can also involve "fights" with enemies, repairing buildings or using tools. Also, the more you're earning experience, the more you're leveling up and the more you're unlocking. There are also chests you can open, with various minigames (and not always easy). Everything is timed and the explorations, as the chests, cost energy.

And that's bothering me, the energy regenerating slowly unless you buy some potions with the crystals you're earning. Crystals are pretty rare but there is the easy way: spent real money to acquire them (or to acquire more golds). Gold is mainly used for weapons for example. Here's an idea for the cost: 10 crystals = 0.88 euros - I've checked the next price and it's already nearing 10 euros). 

I don't mind having quests to do and I don't mind the level up system to access new locations. Even the shop isn't really bothering, as far as you can use the gold you're earning. However, preventing me to play a game because of a decreased energy on Steam, that's something I can't imagine. For me, that kind of gameplay is reminding me of my Facebook games time. Weirdly enough, it would have been on Facebook, I would have find it normal. Here, on Steam, I'm not at ease with the concept. Ubisoft released games about CSI and Assassin's Creed on Facebook, yet, the main series were totally different.

You'll probably find it weird that I'm bothered by the Facebook-like when the game is a free-to-play and that the concept of the energy is also there to push you to buy some (the game is also released on Android and iOS devices). But that's my feeling. Many people will feel that they're trapped and will want to advance. However, I tend to use a simple thought to avoid spending money: there is no rush. You're there for fun (I'm not reading the story though).

As for the rest, the graphics are acceptable and pleasant, the soundtrack being the same. If you played any other Lost Lands, you'll be in an familiar setting.

As I love hidden objects, I can overcome easily the energy bar and the game is still enjoyable. It's free basically, so try it but DON'T FALL INTO THE "NEED ENERGY" TRAP. If there are indeed micro-transactions, don't fall in that pit of addiction. You don't need to go forward immediately. Just quit the game and come back later. It's the best way to play these kind of games, because after all, you're not going to be attacked by another player, your quests aren't timed and besides, why would you rush?

Last for all, why did I thumb up both games when only the gameplay changed? I'm enjoying them, they're free and besides, it's not like I'm wasting my money here...

Le seul soucis réside dans le fait que, pour progresser, il faut refaire sans cesse les mêmes niveaux avec des objets souvent localisés aux mêmes endroits, ce qui limite l'intérêt. Le fait de rassembler du loot à chaque épreuve contribue à rendre le titre addictif. Oui mais voilà, est-ce suffisant pour maintenir l'intérêt à long terme ? Moi je m'y retrouve mais à vous de voir. Ah, et le jeu est gratuit et, avec un peu de patience, je ne vois pas l'intérêt de profiter des micro-transactions, donc c'est un faux problème. Au total, un petit jeu sympa qui mériterait d'être amélioré pour en faire ce qu'il y a de mieux en objets cachés.

21858818.review:
Short version: 
you're better off just paying for a game with some decent reviews than to play this one for free, unless you're only interested in some hidden object scenes and only want to do a few every day.

Pro:
You need to search different areas and look for the listed objects within a certain amount of time. It is nice that sometimes the objects change place or you get different items to look for as the quests require you to search the same area over and over again. 

Cons: 
-It's free to play so enter the micro-transactions! It would be nicer to just pay for a game and getting to enjoy it.
-every hidden object scene costs "energy" (at least 20). Considering it takes a whopping 5 hours to restore 100 energy you are initially given you won't be playing this game for that long per session.
-it even costs energy to open a chest, which is an actual reward after a hidden object scene!
-quests usually require you to collect items you get as rewards but you don't always get your item or you only get 1 while your quest requires 5. Imagine a quest that requires you to get 5x "nails", 5x "wooden board", 3x "rope". Your quest will take days.
-There is no other thing to do here than hidden object scenes (oh and waiting offcourse)

21778983.review:
Hidden object games can be a lot of fun, but they also tend to become tedius after a while. Lost Lands attempts to minimise this by adding several features:

*upgradable structures
*harvestable resources
*puzzle boxes
*enemies which drop materials and collection items.

There is also an ongoing storyline in which you, as an ancient elf king, must befriend several races as you try to restore your race's former glory.

Of course, as an ongoing hidden object game, you will find yourself level grinding during some quests, but that can't be helped in this genre. Overall, it is an excellent game with an interesting cast of characters and enough variety to justify coming back frequently.

Rating: 8/10 for its genre, 6/10 in general
